source: Key BIR Revenue Regulations (RR) and Revenue Memorandum Circulars (RMC)

chunks.title: RR 2-98 - Withholding Tax Regulations (Master)
chunks.content: Revenue Regulations No. 2-98 (as amended by RR 11-2018, RR 14-2018, and subsequent amendments): The master regulation governing the withholding tax system in the Philippines. Covers: (1) Creditable withholding tax (expanded withholding tax / EWT) — taxes withheld at source and creditable against the payee's income tax; (2) Final withholding tax (FWT) — taxes final in nature, not creditable; (3) Withholding tax on compensation — taxes withheld by employers on employee compensation. RR 2-98 prescribes: (a) Income payments subject to EWT and applicable rates (Annex A); (b) Final income payments and applicable rates (Annex B); (c) Obligations of withholding agents; (d) Penalties for non-compliance; (e) Forms to be used (0619-E, 0619-F, 1601-C, 1601-EQ, 1601-FQ, 2307, 2316). Key amendments under TRAIN (RR 11-2018): revised EWT rates for professional fees (5%/10%/15%), increased goods purchase threshold to PHP 3M, and updated compensation withholding tables.

chunks.title: RR 16-2005 - Consolidated VAT Regulations
chunks.content: Revenue Regulations No. 16-2005 (as amended): The consolidated regulations implementing Title IV (VAT) of the NIRC. Key provisions: (1) Defines taxable and exempt transactions; (2) Prescribes rules on VAT registration, invoicing, and record-keeping; (3) Details computation of output VAT and input VAT; (4) Rules on zero-rated sales and VAT refunds; (5) Transitional input VAT for newly VAT-registered taxpayers (2% of inventory value); (6) Presumptive input VAT for processors of sardines, mackerel, and milk (4% of gross value); (7) VAT on sale/lease of real property; (8) VAT on services; (9) VAT on importation. Important amendments: RR 4-2007 (VAT on real property), RR 14-2003 (5% withholding VAT on government sales), RR 13-2018 (TRAIN Law VAT amendments — updated thresholds for residential property exemptions, removed some VAT exemptions). The consolidated VAT regulations are the primary reference for VAT compliance and are frequently cited in BIR audits and CTA cases.

chunks.title: RR 14-2003 - Withholding of VAT on Government Payments
chunks.content: Revenue Regulations No. 14-2003 (as amended by RR 1-2007): Governs the 5% final withholding VAT on government payments. Key rules: (1) All national government agencies (NGAs), government-owned or controlled corporations (GOCCs), local government units (LGUs), and other government instrumentalities must withhold 5% of the gross payment on purchases of goods and services from VAT-registered suppliers; (2) The 5% is the seller's final output VAT on government sales — no additional 12% is charged; (3) The government buyer must remit the 5% withheld using BIR Form 1600; (4) The seller reports the government sale on BIR Form 2550M Line 2 and the 5% on Line 6A; (5) Input VAT related to government sales remains creditable; (6) Government purchases from non-VAT registered persons are not subject to 5% withholding VAT but to applicable EWT rates; (7) Government purchases of goods exempt from VAT (e.g., agricultural products in original state) are also exempt from the 5% withholding VAT.

chunks.title: RR 7-2024 / RR 3-2023 - Digital Economy VAT Rules
chunks.content: Revenue Regulations on VAT for Digital Services (implementing NIRC Section 108 as amended by RA 11976 — Ease of Paying Taxes Act): (1) Digital services consumed in the Philippines are subject to 12% VAT regardless of where the service provider is located; (2) Nonresident digital service providers with annual gross sales exceeding PHP 3,000,000 from Philippine consumers must register for VAT; (3) 'Digital services' include: online advertising, digital content (streaming, e-books, apps), cloud computing, online marketplaces/platforms, software services (SaaS), online gaming, and similar services delivered electronically; (4) Registration: nonresident providers register through a simplified online registration system with the BIR; (5) Filing: quarterly VAT returns (2550Q) and payment in Philippine pesos; (6) Platform operators may be required to withhold and remit VAT on behalf of sellers if the seller is a nonresident; (7) Exempt: B2B transactions where the Philippine business buyer is a VAT-registered person who can claim input VAT. This brings the Philippines in line with OECD guidelines on taxing the digital economy.

chunks.title: RR 12-2024 / RA 11976 - Ease of Paying Taxes Act
chunks.content: Republic Act No. 11976, the Ease of Paying Taxes (EOPT) Act, signed October 2023, effective January 22, 2024. Key provisions implemented through various RRs: (1) Classification of taxpayers into Micro, Small, Medium, and Large — simplified compliance requirements for smaller taxpayers; (2) Simplified return filing — reduced number of required pages and information; (3) Expanded electronic payment options — authorized agents beyond banks; (4) VAT refund improvements — faster processing for zero-rated sellers; (5) Removal of requirement to print ATP on invoices for electronic invoicing system (EIS); (6) Transition to electronic invoicing system (e-Invoicing) — mandatory phased rollout starting with large taxpayers; (7) Filing of returns at any RDO or through electronic channels regardless of RDO assignment; (8) Simplified bookkeeping for micro taxpayers with gross sales below PHP 3M; (9) Automatic BIR registration for new businesses registered with DTI/SEC; (10) Free TIN issuance — removes previous administrative charges.

chunks.title: RMC 57-2020 / RMC 4-2023 - Work From Home and Remote Compliance
chunks.content: BIR Revenue Memorandum Circulars on remote compliance and pandemic-era rules (with continuing relevance): RMC 57-2020: (1) Extended filing deadlines for returns due during COVID-19 ECQ periods; (2) Allowed electronic submission of documents for registration and certification; (3) Permitted photocopied or scanned documents for certain transactions. RMC 4-2023: (1) Clarified that work-from-home arrangements do not change the employee's RDO or the employer's filing obligations; (2) Reiterated that the employer's principal place of business determines the RDO for withholding tax filings; (3) Allowances paid to employees for WFH expenses (internet, electricity) are generally taxable compensation unless qualifying as de minimis or covered by a CBA. Other relevant RMCs: RMC 124-2020 (digital signatures acceptable on BIR forms); RMC 36-2023 (e-Invoicing/e-Receipting pilot program for large taxpayers); RMC 12-2024 (updated list of accredited electronic payment channels).

chunks.title: RR 8-2018 - TRAIN Law Income Tax Implementation
chunks.content: Revenue Regulations No. 8-2018: Implementing rules for the income tax provisions of the TRAIN Law. Key provisions: (1) New withholding tax table for compensation (Annex A) — reflects the 0-35% graduated rates and PHP 250,000 exempt threshold; (2) Rules on the 8% flat tax option — election, computation, filing, and transition; (3) Removal of personal and additional exemptions — no more Status (S, S1, S2, S3, M, M1, etc.) classification for withholding tax computation; (4) Treatment of 13th month pay and other benefits — up to PHP 90,000 exempt; (5) De minimis benefits — updated list and amounts; (6) Substituted filing rules — when BIR 2316 serves as the employee's return; (7) Mixed income earners — rules on combining compensation and business income; (8) Mandatory quarterly income tax returns for self-employed (BIR 1701Q); (9) Transition rules for taxpayers changing from graduated to 8% or vice versa. The compensation withholding table under RR 8-2018 is the primary reference for employers computing monthly withholding tax on employee salaries.

chunks.title: RR 26-2018 / RR 13-2018 - TRAIN Law VAT and Other Amendments
chunks.content: Revenue Regulations implementing TRAIN Law VAT and other tax amendments: RR 13-2018: (1) Updated VAT-exempt thresholds for real property: residential lot up to PHP 1,919,500, house and lot up to PHP 3,199,200 (adjusted for inflation); (2) Lease of residential unit exempt if monthly rental does not exceed PHP 15,000; (3) Removed VAT exemption on raw materials for export-oriented enterprises not registered with PEZA/BOI; (4) Prescription drugs for diabetes, hypertension, and high cholesterol added to VAT-exempt list. RR 26-2018: (1) Estate tax simplified to 6% flat rate with PHP 5M standard deduction; (2) Donor's tax simplified to 6% flat rate with PHP 250,000 annual exemption; (3) Documentary Stamp Tax updates; (4) Percentage tax reduced to 1% (temporarily, later extended by CREATE). RR 25-2018: (1) Excise tax on sweetened beverages; (2) Excise tax on cosmetic surgery/procedures; (3) Updated excise tax on tobacco and alcohol products. These regulations are collectively known as the TRAIN implementing rules and significantly changed compliance requirements for most taxpayers.

chunks.title: Key BIR Rulings and Issuances (2023-2025)
chunks.content: Recent significant BIR issuances (2023-2025): (1) RR 6-2023 — Mandatory use of electronic invoicing/receipting system (EIS) for taxpayers with annual sales exceeding PHP 100M (phased rollout); (2) RMC 105-2023 — Clarification on VAT treatment of digital advertising services by nonresident providers; (3) RR 1-2024 — Updated list of taxpayers mandated to use eFPS; (4) RR 3-2024 — Implementing rules for the Ease of Paying Taxes Act (simplified return forms); (5) RR 7-2024 — VAT on digital services by nonresident providers; (6) RMC 15-2024 — Guidelines on claiming NOLCO for extended period under CREATE Act; (7) RR 12-2024 — Simplified registration for micro taxpayers; (8) RMC 32-2024 — Deadline extensions for certain quarterly returns; (9) RR 15-2024 — CREATE MORE Act implementing rules (enhanced R&D deductions, permanent 1% MCIT, 1% percentage tax extension). Note: BIR issuances are published on the BIR website (bir.gov.ph) and in the Official Gazette. Taxpayers should always verify the latest issuances as rules are frequently updated.

chunks.title: Tax Treaty Network and Relief
chunks.content: The Philippines has signed and ratified tax treaties (Double Taxation Agreements/DTAs) with over 40 countries. Key treaty provisions: (1) Reduced withholding tax rates on dividends (typically 10-15% vs. 25% domestic rate), interest (10-15% vs. 20%), and royalties (10-25% vs. 30%); (2) Permanent establishment (PE) rules — defines when a foreign enterprise is deemed to have a taxable presence in the Philippines; (3) Elimination of double taxation — either by credit method or exemption method; (4) Exchange of information provisions. Treaty countries include: USA, UK, Japan, China, South Korea, Singapore, Australia, Canada, Germany, France, India, Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia, and others. To claim treaty benefits: (a) File BIR Form 0901 (Tax Treaty Relief Application/TTRA) — no longer required for most treaty claims per RMC 14-2021; (b) Self-assessment approach — withholding agent applies the treaty rate directly, subject to BIR verification; (c) Certificate of Residence (COR) from the nonresident's home country required. Non-compliance: if treaty rate is applied without proper documentation, the BIR may assess deficiency withholding taxes with surcharge and interest.
